Ethylene sulfate (DTD) is a new type of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film-forming additive for lithium-ion batteries. DTD was typically synthesized in the industry by oxidation of ethylene sulfite (ES) with NaClO via a RuCl3-catalyzed reaction. However, this route generates significant amount of Cl-containing wastes, and the recovery of RuCl3 is costly and technically challenging. Herein, we present a green and heterogeneous route for synthesizing DTD from ES, utilizing the Titanium Silicalite-1 (TS-1) and H2O2 as catalysts and green oxidants, respectively. Our research reveals that the tetra-coordination framework of Ti in TS-1 serves as the main active site for the oxidation of ES, achieving a remarkable yield of DTD up to 92 % under optimized reaction conditions. Additionally, we developed a continuous green oxidation process for synthesizing DTD from ES, which is the first of its kind and has been successfully operated continuously for over 300 h. This work provides a cost-effective, green, and efficient route for synthesizing DTD from ES. Among these technologies, lithium-ion batteries have found widespread applications in energy storage and consumer applications. Lithium-ion batteries mainly comprise electrode materials, electrolytes, separators, and battery shells. Among them, electrolytes are critical for the thermal stability and safety performance of lithium-ion batteries [1–3]. By adding a small amount of additives (typically accounting for about 5 wt% of the electrolyte) to the electrolyte, the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formed between the electrode and electrolyte can be stabilized, thereby enhancing the electrical performance, safety, and lifespan of lithium-ion batteries [4–6]. Therefore, the development and application of electrolyte additives have garnered increasing attention from the industry in recent years. Unsaturated carbonates, sulfur-containing compounds, and lithium salts are the most widely used additives among SEI film-forming additives [7–9]. Among these additives, ethylene sulfate (DTD) exhibits excellent compatibility with silicon-based anodes, improving low-temperature performance, increasing initial discharge capacity, and suppressing battery expansion [10,11]. It holds significant potential for application as a new electrolyte additive. In addition, DTD is also widely used in synthesizing medical intermediates and surfactants [12–14]. Over the past few decades, researchers have developed a variety of pathways for synthesizing DTD, including substitution [15], acylation [16,17], and addition reactions [18,19], as illustrated in Fig. 1. However, these methods are often limited by low DTD yields or the generation of halogen-containing waste, which contradicts the principles of green and sustainable chemistry. Recently, an oxidation route for synthesizing DTD from ES under mild conditions has gained attention due to its room-temperature operation. Using noble metal catalysts (e.g., RuO4, RuCl3, ReCl3, RhCl3) and oxidants such as NaIO4 or NaClO, the synthesis of DTD from ES can be achieved in batch reactors or microchannel reactors, with yields exceeding 90 % [20–24]. However, the high cost of noble metals and the challenges for the recovery remain significant drawbacks. Therefore, using Cu or Fe as catalysts to oxidize ES to DTD with oxidants such as tert-butyl hydroperoxide or sodium percarbonate have been developed [25,26]. The industrialization of synthesizing DTD from ES has been achieved using RuCl3 and NaClO as catalyst and oxidant, respectively [27,28]. However, this homogeneous batch process is costly due to the difficulty of recovering RuCl3 and generates metal salt by-products and Cl-containing wastes. Therefore, developing a heterogeneous and green route for synthesizing DTD from ES is of great interest and importance. A heterogeneous route for ES oxidation to DTD can be achieved using a complex catalyst composed of CuO, MnO, and Al2O3, with O3 or MnO4 - [29] as oxidant. However, this method often faces catalyst deactivation due to acidic by-products generated from the hydrolysis of DTD [30]. An alternative approach involves using Titanium Silicalite-1 (TS-1) as the catalyst with H2O2 as the oxidant, providing a green and pollution-free route for DTD synthesis [31,32]. Although this process enables a heterogeneous reaction, it yields only 43 % DTD and is limited to batch reactors, which restricts its industrial applicability [32]. While micro-packed bed reactors can enhance the yield of DTD, their industrial scale-up remains challenging. Additionally, residual acetone in the product may adversely affect the performance of lithium-ion batteries [31]. Given these limitations, developing a green, scalable, and continuous process for synthesizing DTD from ES is essential. In this study, the form of active Ti species and oxidation activity were optimized by adjusting the preparation conditions of TS-1. The relationship between catalyst structure and catalytic performance was investigated by combining XRD, UV-Vis, NH3-TPD, and SEM characterizations. The results showed that the tetra-coordination framework Ti in TS-1 serves as the active site for ES oxidation. H2O2 is initially dissociated into Ti-OOH species at the tetra-coordination Ti sites, which serves as a key intermediate in the catalytic reaction. Based on these findings, a continuous flow reactor was designed to achieve the first green, heterogeneous, and continuous synthesis of DTD from ES. At a WHSV of 16.2 h−1, the selectivity of DTD can reach more than 90 %, and can stably run for more than 300 h, providing a new route for the industrial synthesis of DTD. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 99 %), tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT,98 %), and tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (TPAOH, 25 wt%) were purchased from Anhui Zesheng Technology Co. Ltd. Isopropanol (IPA, 99.5 %) and amine bicarbonate (NH4HCO3) was purchased from Aladdin. Ethylene sulphite (ES, 99 %) and ethylene sulfate (DTD, 98 %) were used as received from Macklin. H2O2 (AR) was obtained from Xilong Scientific Co. Ltd. All these chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation TS-1 was prepared via a hydrothermal method, as reported earlier [33]. Typically, TPAOH was mixed with deionized water at room temperature under stirring for 10 min, followed by the dropwise addition of 5.0 g TEOS. The resulting slurry was stirred for 3 h in a 70 °C oil bath. Following this, TBOT/IPA was added dropwise to the silica sol after cooling to room temperature, and then NH4HCO3 was added. The mixture was evaporated at 80°C to remove the alcohol, resulting in a clear sol. The sol was supplemented with an appropriate amount of water. The obtained gel had a molar ratio of 1.0 SiO2:(0.01–0.1) TiO2:(0.1–0.7) TPAOH:(0–1.05) NH4HCO3:30 H2O, transferred to an autoclave, and heated at 170 °C for 24–96 h. At the end of crystallization, the slurry was centrifuged, washed, and dried overnight at 80 °C. The obtained solid was ground into a fine powder and calcined in flowing air at 550°C for 6 h to remove the organic template. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal phase structure of the sample was precisely determined using X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα rays (λ=1.54056 Å), operated at 40 kV, 40 mA, over a scanning range of 5–45°. The UV–vis spectra were acquired on a PerkinElmer Lambda 1050 + UV/Vis/NIR spectrophotometers to analyze the coordination state of titanium in TS-1. Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) data were collected using a ThermoFisher Nicolet iS50 spectrometer to evaluate the titanium species in the TS-1 zeolite samples. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was characterized using an Auto Chem Ⅱ 2920 chemissorbent meter (McMurray Tick, Inc. USA). Typically, 100 mg of TS-1 was pre-treated in 10 % O2/He flow at 300 °C for 1 h. Then, the sample was cooled to 50 °C and exposed to a 10 % NH3/He flow for 1 h, followed by raising the temperature at a heating rate of 10 °C/min to 800 °C in He atmosphere to desorb the NH3. N2 sorption measurements were conducted using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 automated sorption system. The catalyst was vacuum degassed at 300 °C for 4 h before testing. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) was carried out using a Regulus 8100 scanning electron microscope scanned at a low accelerating voltage of 5 kV. The in situ Raman spectra is conducted using a CAS-Kelly Irispec Laser Raman Spectrometer with an acquisition time of 60 s. During the in situ experiments, 30 mg of TS-1 was compressed into a 10-mm-diameter pellet using a custom die with radial grooves (0.2 mm depth × 0.5 mm width), and then place it on the sample stage. A 257 nm laser line was used as the excitation source to collected the spectra at different time, a 325 nm laser line was used to identify the physisorbed H2O2 on TS-1. The Si/Ti ratio and titanium content of the TS-1 sample were measured by ICP-MS. The TEM, HAADF-STEM, and EDS elemental mapping were performed on a JEOL JEM-F200 electron microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a ESCALAB QXi (Thermo Scientific) using Al Kα radiation (1846.6 eV) as the X-ray source. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation 2.4.1 Ethylene sulfate synthesis in a batch reactor A jacketed batch reactor was used to investigate the relationship between the structure of TS-1 and its catalytic performance in the oxidation of ES. Typically, the solvent and catalyst were first added to the reactor. After thorough mixing, ethylene sulfate (ES) was introduced, and the temperature of the circulating water bath in the jacket was set to the reaction temperature (35°C-55°C). Subsequently, H2O2 was added slowly using a syringe pump. 2.4.2 Ethylene sulfate synthesis in a continuous flow reactor A homemade continuous flow reactor was designed to achieve the continuous synthesis of ethylene sulfate (DTD), as shown in Fig. S1. The reactor features a catalyst bed with an inner diameter of 8 mm and a bed height of 5 cm, loaded with 2 g of catalyst (30–40 mesh). A low-temperature separation bottle was maintained at 5 °C to inhibit the hydrolysis of DTD. The experimental parameters such as temperature, flow rate, and reactant concentration were systematically adjusted. After each experiment, the catalyst bed was sequentially cleaned with ethanol and solvent to remove any residual reactants or by-products. Additional details regarding the reactor design and operation are provided in the supplementary material. 2.4.3 Products analysis The reaction products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2010) equipped with an SH-I-17 column and a flame ionization detector (FID). Based on the reaction between Ti4+ and H2O2 in an acidic medium, the conversion of H2O2 was detected by UV-Vis spectrophotometry. Different Ti-containing catalysts were evaluated in this study, and the results are shown in Table 1. Among these catalysts, only TS-1 and TS-2 exhibited oxidative activity toward ES. This may be attributed to the incorporation of Ti into a crystalline framework in TS-1 and TS-2, whereas Ti is present in an amorphous form in other catalysts. It is worth noting that when H2O2 is used as the oxidant, TS-1 demonstrates significantly higher activity than TS-2, which may be related to differences in pore structure and hydrophilicity between the two catalysts. TS-2 has a straight pore structure and higher hydrophilicity, which hinders the adsorption of ES and H2O2 on the framework Ti species [34–38]. The oxidation reaction of ES was monitored over time using TS-1 as the catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. S2. After 3.5 h of reaction, the reaction reached equilibrium, with ES conversion and DTD yield reaching 95 % and 91 %, respectively. However, as the reaction continued, the hydrolysis of DTD occurred, which resulted in a decrease in DTD yield. A 2 h reaction time was selected as the standard condition to enable rigorous comparison of catalyst performance, unless explicitly stated otherwise. 3.2 The effect of preparation conditions on the catalytic performance of TS-1 for ES oxidation The Si/Ti molar ratio in TS-1 was systematically varied by adjusting the initial molar ratio of TEOS and TBOT to investigate the influence of the acidity of TS-1 on its catalytic performance. Changing the Si/Ti molar ratio did not alter the structure of TS-1, which retained the MFI topology, as shown in Fig. S3. The actual Si/Ti ratios and Ti contents of the synthesized TS-1 samples are summarized in Table S1. It was observed that the Si/Ti ratio in the TS-1 increased correspondingly with the Si/Ti ratio in the synthesis gel. Consequently, the Ti content decreased, reaching 1.5 wt% at a gel Si/Ti ratio of 40. The catalytic performance of TS-1 with different Si/Ti for ES oxidation is shown in Fig. 2a. The results showed that TS-1 exhibited the best catalytic performance when the Si/Ti molar ratio was 40, achieving an ES conversion of 84 % and a DTD yield of 74 % in 2 h. TS-1 with different n(Si/Ti) was characterized by NH3-TPD, and the results are shown in Fig. 2b. The weak acid site peak at 103 °C is attributed to the unsaturated coordination framework Ti in TS-1. In comparison, the strong acid site near 680 °C is attributed to the Si-OH adjacent to the Ti sites in TS-1 and anatase TiO2 [39,40]. With an increase in the Si/Ti molar ratio, the proportion of weak acid sites gradually increased, and the catalytic performance of TS-1 for ES oxidation also improved, as shown in Table S2. When the Si/Ti molar ratio is 40, which is close to the maximum theoretical framework Ti content (2.5 mol%) of TS-1 [41], the weak acid content of TS-1 reaches its maximum, and the catalyst activity is also the highest, as shown in Fig. 2 and Table S2. With a gradual increase in the Si/Ti molar ratio, the content of framework Ti in TS-1 gradually decreased, and the weak acid sites were reduced. In contrast, the strong acid sites gradually increased, leading to a progressive decrease in the catalytic performance of TS-1. Furthermore, the utilization of H2O2 decreases with an increasing density of strong acid sites, likely due to the acid-catalyzed decomposition of H2O2. These results demonstrated that increasing Ti content within the framework enhances the proportion of weak acid sites in TS-1, thereby improving its catalytic performance for ES oxidation. However, excessive Ti content promotes the formation of surface anatase TiO2, which covers the active framework Ti sites and increases strong acid sites, ultimately diminishing catalytic efficiency. The presence of Ti in TS-1 significantly influences its catalytic performance, as demonstrated in acidity research. To change the Ti species, mineralizing agent (NH4HCO3) was introduced during the preparation of TS-1 [42,43]. As shown in Fig. S4, the addition of NH4HCO3 does not alter the MFI topology of TS-1. However, the catalytic performance of TS-1 is notably enhanced by incorporating an optimal amount of NH4HCO3 during the synthesis process ( Fig. 3a). UV-Vis spectroscopy (Fig. 3b) reveals a strong absorption peak at 320 nm in the absence of NH4HCO3, attributed to the formation of anatase TiO2 on the surface of TS-1 [44]. With the addition of NH4HCO3, the intensity of this peak gradually decreases. Simultaneously, the absorption peak at 210 nm becomes more pronounced, which is associated with the electronic transition from the 2p orbital of oxygen near tetra-coordination framework Ti to the 3d empty orbital of Ti [44]. However, excessive NH4HCO3 during TS-1 synthesis leads to the reformation of anatase TiO2 on the surface, which promotes H2O2 decomposition [45] and consequently reduces catalytic performance. The highest H2O2 utilization, observed at an NH4HCO3/TPAOH molar ratio of 0.5, is attributed to the increased incorporation of titanium into the zeolite framework. Framework Ti species are crucial for activating H2O2 to form Ti-OOH active intermediates, which effectively catalyze the oxidation of ES, thereby enhancing the utilization of H2O2. TEM reveals that TS-1 synthesized without NH4HCO3 exhibits isolated TiO2 clusters on its surface (Fig. S5), consistent with the anatase TiO2 signature (binding energy of 456.8 eV) in the Ti 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. S6) [46]. In contrast, the TS-1 prepared with an NH4HCO3/TPAOH ratio of 0.5 possesses a well-defined morphology and exhibits a dominant XPS peak at 460.0 eV, which is characteristic of tetra-coordinated framework Ti [47,48]. This effective incorporation of Ti into the framework minimizes the formation of inactive anatase TiO2 that catalyzes the non-productive decomposition of H2O2, thus rationalizing the optimal catalytic performance observed at this specific ratio. These findings suggest that an appropriate amount of NH4HCO3 suppresses the formation of anatase TiO2 and facilitates the incorporation of tetra-coordinated Ti into the framework, potentially serving as the active site for ES oxidation. Furthermore, NH4HCO3 stabilizes TPAOH against decomposition and promotes the crystallization and formation of TS-1 [49]. The catalytic performance of TS-1 prepared under different hydrothermal times for ES oxidation was investigated. As shown in Fig. S7, the crystallinity of TS-1 progressively improved with prolonged hydrothermal time. FT-IR characterization of TS-1 revealed an asymmetric stretching vibration peak of Si-O-Ti at 960 cm−1, as shown in Fig. 4b and Fig. 4c, confirming the successful incorporation of Ti into the TS-1 framework [50,51]. Additionally, the peak at 550 cm−1 was attributed to the double frequency vibration in a five-membered ring of MFI topology [52]. I 960/I 550 is commonly used to quantify the relative content of framework Ti species [53], as shown in Table S3. With extended hydrothermal time, both the crystallinity of TS-1 and the relative content of framework Ti increased. As the hydrothermal time was extended from 24 h to 48 h, the conversion of ES increased from 74 % to 84 %, and the yield of DTD rose from 60 % to 74 %, as shown in Fig. 4a. These results strongly suggest that the framework Ti in TS-1 serves as the most likely active site for ES oxidation. The morphology of TS-1 was modified by adjusting the template TPAOH content during its preparation. All samples exhibited an MFI topology, as shown in Fig. S8. However, when n(TPAOH/Si) = 0.1, the catalytic activity of TS-1 was only half of that observed at n(TPAOH/Si) = 0.25, as shown in Fig. 5a. SEM characterization of TS-1 prepared with different TPAOH content is shown in Fig. 5b-5f. At n(TPAOH/Si) = 0.1, TS-1 displayed a large block-like structure. As the TPAOH content increased, the morphology transitioned to an elliptical shape with a grooved surface, which likely enhanced the exposure of framework Ti on the surface of TS-1, thereby improving its catalytic performance. Additionally, the particle size of TS-1 gradually decreased with increasing TPAOH content. The grooved ellipsoid morphology may also contribute to an increased BET surface area. To further investigate this, TS-1 with different BET surface areas were prepared by adding the surfactant P123 during the preparation process. The BET surface area and pore size were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments (Fig. S9 and Table S4). The results indicated that increasing the P123 content led to higher BET surface areas and larger pore sizes. However, the catalytic performance of TS-1 for ES oxidation did not significantly change (Fig. S10). This may be attributed to the fact that, despite the increased pore size, the accessibility of ES to the active sites remained limited, resulting in negligible changes in the exposure of framework Ti on the TS-1 surface. Therefore, modifying the surface morphology of TS-1 is an effective strategy to expose more framework Ti, thereby enhancing its catalytic performance. 3.3 Solvent screening Some commonly used solvents were screened in the batch reaction, as shown in Table S5. When dimethyl carbonate (DMC), dichloromethane (DCM), or methanol was used as the solvent, the conversion of ES reached up to 60 %. However, only with DMC could the selectivity of DTD reach 88 %, whereas it was below 50 % with the other solvents. This contrasts with the RuCl3-NaClO system, which typically employs DCM as the solvent. Notably, DMC is widely used to dissolve electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries. Compared to the RuCl3-NaClO system, the use of DMC in this reaction not only simplifies the subsequent separation of DTD but also minimizes the potential impact of residual solvents on lithium-ion battery performance. 3.4 Mechanism of ES oxidation catalyzed by TS-1 The oxidation mechanism was probed by in-situ Raman spectroscopy using 325 nm and 257 nm laser lines. After dropping 10 μL of 30 wt% H2O2 on the surface of TS-1, a new band at 887 cm−1 appeared under 325 nm laser line, which assigned to physisorbed H2O2 in TS-1 [54]. With the extension of time, the intensity of physisorbed H2O2 gradually decayed, as shown in Fig. S9. From the Raman spectra collected with a 257 nm laser line, the bands at 650 cm−1 (attributable to the rocking vibration of Ti-OH [55]) was significantly quenched immediately upon addition of H2O2, and no Raman signal attributable to physisorbed H2O2 was detected. Meanwhile, a new band at 823 cm−1, attributed to the O-O stretching of Ti-OOH [54,56], appeared and gradually intensified, until reaching equilibrium within 10 min, as shown in Fig. 6a. This Ti-OOH species is generated through the dissociation of H2O2 at tetra-coordinated framework Ti sites [57]. Further addition of H2O2 enhanced the Ti-OOH intensity, confirming the continuous activation of H2O2 at these sites. When 10 μL 20 mM of ES/DMC solution was added to the TS-1/H2O2 system, the 823 cm-¹ vibrational mode gradually decreased, concurrent with the appearance of a new band at 758 cm−1, which assigned to adsorbed DTD on the surface of TS-1, as shown in Fig. 6b. Its intensity first increased and then decreased over time, indicating its gradual desorption from the TS-1 surface, as shown in Fig. 6c. Complete desorption was observed within 30 min. Subsequent addition of 10 μL 30 wt% H2O2 restored the Ti-OOH band intensity, confirming the regeneration of active sites. These results suggest that H2O2 first adsorbs on the surface of TS-1, and then rapidly dissociates at the tetra-coordinated framework Ti to form Ti-OOH active intermediates, and these intermediates rapidly oxidize ES to DTD. 3.5 TS-1 continuous catalytic oxidation of ES to synthesize DTD During ES oxidation in the batch reactor, TS-1 agglomerates and adheres to the reactor wall, as shown in Fig. S10, hindering solid-liquid mass transfer. Additionally, ES oxidation is highly exothermic, it is difficult to remove the heat of the reaction in time when it is carried out in a batch reactor, so there are safety risks such as fire and explosion. Moreover, DTD readily hydrolyzes to sulfuric acid and glycol upon contact with water (from aqueous H2O2). Experiments revealed that DTD hydrolysis accelerates with TS-1 addition, as shown in Fig. S11, indicating that the hydrolysis of DTD occurs on the catalyst's surface. A hot filtration test was performed on the reaction mixture after 1 h to assess the heterogeneity of the catalytic system. After removal of the solid TS-1 catalyst by hot filtration, the reaction in the filtrate showed no further conversion of ES, and the yield of DTD remained unchanged. These results unequivocally demonstrate that the active sites for both the oxidation of ES and the subsequent hydrolysis of DTD are intrinsically heterogeneous and reside on the TS-1 surface, with no evidence of leaching of active species (Table S6). Therefore, timely heat removal and product separation from the catalyst surface are critical. To address these issues, a continuous reactor was designed, as shown in Fig. S1, leveraging forced flow for efficient heat dissipation and product extraction. Based on batch reactor studies, TS-1 prepared with n(Si/Ti) = 40, n(TPAOH/Si) = 0.25, n(NH4HCO3/TPAOH) = 0.5, and 48 h hydrothermal time was selected for continuous DTD synthesis. N2 purging was employed to enhance product removal and heat transfer. The effects of catalyst bed temperature, substrate concentration, and weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) on ES oxidation were systematically investigated. The effect of catalyst bed temperature on ES oxidation was studied in a continuous flow reactor by controlling the system temperature, as shown in Fig. 7a. Both ES conversion and DTD yield increased with temperature, and 55 °C was selected as the optimal condition, balancing high performance (96 % conversion, 88 % yield) with safety. Increasing the N2 flow rate (0–200 mL/min) had negligible impact on conversion and yield, as shown in Fig. 7b. However, without N2 purging, the bed temperature rose sharply from 35 °C to 41.7 °C in 30 min, as shown in Fig. S12, whereas at 100 mL/min N2, it stabilized at 37.4 °C after a brief increase to 38 °C. This result indicates that appropriate carrier gas helps to remove reactants and reaction heat in time and keep the stability of the reaction system. ES concentration increased from 2 wt% to 10 wt%, the conversion and DTD yield reduced from 94 % to 77 %, 90–58 %, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7c. Especially when ES concentration was more significant than 6 wt%, DTD selectivity decreased rapidly. The decrease in DTD selectivity is likely because higher ES concentration increases H2O2 demand, thereby introducing more water (from aqueous H2O2) and promoting DTD hydrolysis. Similarly, higher WHSV (0.5–2.5 h-¹) lowered conversion and yield by shortening residence time on TS-1, though selectivity remained constant, as shown in Fig. 7d. Based on these results, under the optimal reaction conditions (55 °C, N2 flow rate of 100 mL/min, ES concentration of 4 wt%, and WHSV of 16.2 h−1), ES was completely converted, achieving a DTD yield of 92 %. Based on the optimized reaction conditions in the continuous flow reactor, considering both experimental safety and practical application, the lifetime of TS-1 for ES oxidation was evaluated under the reaction conditions of 35 °C, N2 flow rate of 100 mL/min, ES concentration of 4 wt%, and WHSV of 16.2 h−1. The catalyst bed temperature during the reaction was also measured. As shown in Fig. 8, TS-1 exhibited stable catalytic performance over 300 h, with ES conversion maintained at 72 %, DTD yield at 65 %, and selectivity consistently above 90 %. The catalyst bed temperature remained stable at approximately 36 °C throughout the reaction. XRD analysis confirmed that the TS-1 structure was preserved after 300 h reaction, as shown in Fig. S13. These results demonstrate the stable and efficient catalytic performance of TS-1 for ES oxidation, highlighting its potential for industrial-scale DTD production. 4 Conclusion We developed a stable, heterogeneous, and continuous method for synthesizing DTD from ES using H2O2 as a green oxidant and TS-1 as a catalyst. This approach avoids the use of costly Ru3+ catalysts and NaClO oxidants employed in conventional routes, significantly reducing production costs and Cl-containing waste generation. Through systematic TS-1 synthesis optimization, we maximized tetra-coordinated framework Ti while suppressing anatase TiO2 formation. In the ES oxidation, these tetra-coordinated framework Ti first activate H2O2 to form a Ti-OOH reactive intermediate, which then oxidizes ES to DTD. Using this TS-1 as a catalyst, ES was almost completely converted, and the yield of DTD reached over 92 % under optimal conditions. TS-1 exhibited high stability, maintaining its catalytic activity even after 300 h of continuous reaction, with the catalyst bed temperature varying by less than ±1.0 °C. This work presents the heterogeneous catalytic system for continuous DTD production using H2O2 as a green oxidant, demonstrating significant potential for industrial-scale synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Ethylene sulfate (DTD) is a new type of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film-forming additive for lithium-ion batteries. DTD was typically synthesized in the industry by oxidation of ethylene sulfite (ES) with NaClO via a RuCl3-catalyzed reaction. However, this route generates significant amount of Cl-containing wastes, and the recovery of RuCl3 is costly and technically challenging. Herein, we present a green and heterogeneous route for synthesizing DTD from ES, utilizing the Titanium Silicalite-1 (TS-1) and H2O2 as catalysts and green oxidants, respectively. Our research reveals that the tetra-coordination framework of Ti in TS-1 serves as the main active site for the oxidation of ES, achieving a remarkable yield of DTD up to 92 % under optimized reaction conditions. Additionally, we developed a continuous green oxidation process for synthesizing DTD from ES, which is the first of its kind and has been successfully operated continuously for over 300 h. This work provides a cost-effective, green, and efficient route for synthesizing DTD from ES.
